comments.text: one of the biggest differences between a calculator and a computer is that a calculator is a simple input and output machine. one number goes in and another comes out, but a computer has the ability to interpret the input and make a series of outputs. One of the first examples of such a machine was developed in the 1830s by John Graham-Cumming. There is a TED talk that explains how he designed a steam powered computational engine that was more like a computer than a calculator.

This is a mouth stick designed as assistive technology for a person with no use of their hands, and is used to type on keyboards, flip pages in books, and to dial phones. When printed with a conductive plastic it will work with capacitance touch screens such as the iPad, iPhone, and Android tablets. The one I printed is made with Protopasta. There is a conductive foam tip installed in the end to made it more responsive. I used a small piece cut from a fresh, unused ScotchBrite sponge, but any conductive sponge will do. Once the typing cuff is printed, it can be custom sized and bends made by heating it up with a heat gun.
For more information on assistive technology, visit http://www.rehabengineer.com, or our agency at http://rehab.alabama.gov/ .

Make your iPhone more accessible and secure with the Wall Dock. This puts your iPhone out of the way and gets it off your nightstand where it's at risk of getting knocked off. It also keeps your cord secured and ready to use. No more untangling or digging for a rogue cord. Instructions:
  • Nail it flush and level into any drywall with two finish nails. Drive nails until the dock is held securely and the nail heads are below the top surface of the dock.
  • Feed Lightning cord through the left hole. Slide cord to the right. Press Lightning connector into right hole. The Lighting connector fit should be tight enough so that it remains in place when removing the phone.
  • Slide phone into slot. Press until lightning connector is fully seated into iPhone. Remove phone by pulling up.
  • Remove Lightning cord by pushing it out of its hole from the bottom with either a screwdriver or small rod.
    • Designed for:
  • iPhone 6 with Insignia case
    • http://www.bestbuy.com/site/insignia-perforated-case-for-apple-iphone-6-and-6s-black/8451331.p?id=1219334913007&skuId=8451331
  • Official Apple Lightning Usb Cable
    • http://www.apple.com/shop/product/MD818AM/A/lightning-to-usb-cable
  • Finish Nails
    • http://www.amazon.com/The-Hillman-Group-532584-90-Pack/dp/B00PHHQ9LA/ref=pd_sim_60_3?ie=UTF8&dpID=31lNKVg3ydL&dpSrc=sims&preST=_AC_UL160_SR160%2C160_&refRID=0KX55SEZCNSC6RV1J3F4

title: Ipad holder for Lowe's wire shelf - 25.5mm

description.text:
I wanted an iPad Air holder for the shelf that holds my computer stuff.  I can use the iPad as a second monitor or just use the IPad Air as separate browser or app or whatever.
This holder should fit many Ipad models from Mini, to Air, to Pro.  It should also have no trouble with many other tablet brands.  The shelf width is 15 mm which hold my Ipad Air with an Apple case.  It works in vertical or horizontal, with a gap for the iPad charging/USB/Lightning cable.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm layers

Infill:

30% hexagon

Notes: The one pictured is printed in PETG with three walls, two bottom, and two tops. Be careful if you are using support for the clips, it can get difficult to remove and cause breakage.

To assemble, trim, file, or sand as needed to get a good fit.  You should not have to shove these together.
Also notice there is a taper to the slide-in tabs and a matching taper on the tubing clips.  Make sure your clips are aligned correctly.
Attach the clips to the shelf and slide in the base tabs until snug.  Check that your base is square to the tube.  Now add a few drops of superglue to tack the pieces together.
After it is dry, remove the assembled base piece and flood the joint area with more superglue and allow it to cure.
Repeat these steps for the top piece.  You may need to shim your shelf tubing with some tape to firm up the grip, depending on your printer.

Micro SD adapters toast, the best complement for Thor-ster SD Although you can print of a piece, is not recommended because it would have to use supports and space for microSD is very small. It is very easy to damage the piece to remove them.
Instead it is better to print on both parts and glue them later. If ABS is used, put a little acetone in parts with a brush and press. PLA would have to use glue.

Tostadas adaptadoras para microSD, el mejor complemento para la Thor-ster SD. Aunque se puede imprimir de una pieza, no es recomendable porque habría que usar soportes y el espacio para la microSD es muy pequeño. Es muy fácil dañar la pieza al quitarlos.
En lugar de eso es mejor imprimir las dos partes y pegarlas después. Si se usa ABS, poniendo un poco de acetona en las partes con un pincel y presionando se pega fácilmente. Con PLA habría que usar pegamento.

author: Shii

description.text:
This is a scan of my Alchemy Gothic™ :: Omega Skull
http://www.alchemygothic.com/index.php?option=com_ag_cat_bridge&agpage=i_ASS51_Omega_Skull.html&Itemid=105 My first attempt at Photogrammetry with 'Agisoft PhotoScan'.
Also this was my first time using 'Blender'. The entire process, took roughly 15Hrs. ~7Hrs waiting for 'Agisoft PhotoScan' to do its magic. This software is insanely EASY to use,
and getting amazing results is as easy as 1, 2, 3. I used this guys tutorial, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GEsRcFQ1_H8 ~5Hrs with 'Blender 2.76b', making the model solid, making a flat bottom,
and smoothing some bumpyness in the eyesockets.
-(I normally only use 'SketchUp', this was NOT an option here)- +3.5Hrs printing. Printed on my K8200 w. E3DV6 and auto tramming. 3mm PLA. 0.4mm Nozzle
0.25mm Layer height Extruder temp. 200c.
Bed temp 60c.
Print fan disabled. (Or, well... i broke it.) Model scaled to 65mm Height.
-(Wanted to go fullsize, but with crappy inconsistent PLA between 2.75mm & 3.05mm
and +16Hrs print time, this will have to wait.)- I was printing quite slow at 60 mm/s.
No support material.
Using Rafts.
3 Outer perimeters.
2 Solid top & bottom layers.
20% Infill. Overall i'm very pleased with the result.

remixed_from.author: Allted
remixed_from.title: Mostly Printed CNC -Add On- Pipe Clamp 90

description.text:
I needed something for my large bed MPCNC to hold my filament spool and keep the filament feed lines out of the way during the print. 
I designed this system to hold a 5mm Teflon filament guide tube.  It will hold most spools I am sure.  It will fit a stock MPCNC, but should have no trouble being adapted as you see fit.
This design sources parts from other sources as noted.  I have included all the files needed here, so you can get them in one place.  The parts have color references based on my pictures.  There are other EMT cap styles available from the Remix link.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm layers

Infill:

50%

Notes: You will probably need supports for the large funnel parts, but not the other stuff. You need to print 4 caps, 4 centers, and 1 each of the remaining parts

Assembly You will need eight #6x3" and five #6x1" machine bolts with matching lock nuts. On my machine I used a 20" EMT tube for the upright pole and a 6" long tube for the spool arm. Be careful tightening the nuts. These things do not need large amount of torque to hold them together. The gantry fairlead funnel should just slide over the NEMA 17 Z-axis motor. The gantry filament guide arm clamps onto the Z-axis EMT using two 1" bolts. You should be able to align the hole in the guide arm up with the corner under the funnel. On the spool side, loosely assemble two of the EMT clamps using the 3" screws. On the lower set of 90º clamps, insert the center spacer block so you will clear the MPCNC corner brackets. Attach the lower assembled 90ºblocks and slide in the 24" EMT tube. Next attach the other 90º clamp assembly to the spool holder EMT and slide it onto the long arm and clamp it where convenient for your spool diameters. Add the clamp collar with a 1" bolt/nut to secure it. Then add the filament guide arm and finally, the filament fairlead funnel using 1" bolts/nuts. Place the parts so the arm guide hole aligns with the corner of the funnel and all this lines up on the middle of your spool. Cut your PTFE tubing to the length you need and insert one end into your MK8 extruder and the other end into the spool guide arm, feeding through all the guides. Load your spool, feed your filament, and get to printing.

title: Tensioner Latch for Greg's Wade Reload Extruder

description.text: This is a latch for the Greg's Wade Reload extruder's tension arm. It makes it much easier to release the tensioner and lock it back in place for faster filament changes. You will need to get 5mm longer screws for the tensioner springs to use this. Also do not forget to put washers in between the springs and the block. There is built in support material for the holes that should just snap right now as there is a half millimeter gap between them and the actual block. This should work with just about any of the wade or greg-wade accessible extruders as long as the tensioner bolts are around 16.5mm apart. The one I am currently using this with is this guy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27054 As always I have included the sketchup file so people can make changes as need be.

I recently started brewing my coffee the proper way, using a Bialetti Moka Express. You might know it as an "espresso" maker (despite the fact technically it's not really espresso due to the lack of pressure!) I found that there was often times I'd like to be able to prepare the coffee in the funnel part without it being inserted into the lower half of the Moka Pot. The main reason being that if in a hurry, preboiling the water in the kettle leads less time sitting on the stove (I always have it Americano so the kettle needs to be boiled too anyway.) I created this stand so that I could have the funnel kept upright and stable without needing to be inside the pot (once in there, you can't get the blighter out without spilling your grounds everywhere.) It has a nice wide base and I've tested it with the funnels from pots that can brew up to four cups. I added a tiny hole at the bottom so any drips of water don't collect inside the part and it's all open so that you won't every get a build up of coffee grounds either. Finally, the top is bowled[?] out so that it sits in really nicely and there is even space for the lip right where the tube meets the basket (if your pot has one.)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or lower

Infill:

30-40%

Notes: This part gets used multiple times a day in our house so needed to be really rugged and reliable. So I printed with 4 outer shells, 4 top and bottom solid layers and 40% infill. I also wanted it to be aesthetically pleasing, so I used Concentric top and bottom solid layer patterns, which makes it look really attractive, too (one of the reasons I really prefer Sli3R to Cura is the control over the end finish.) Mine is printed in Silver PLA from Rigid.ink but really it doesn't matter what you use. It won't ever get hot so use whatever is to hand. Printing at 0.2mm or lower will make sure that the curves are all well smoothed and makes it look more pleasing overall.

author: maiknms

description.text:
Update: Added some gaps in the edges to facilitate extracting the bottom cards. Sorry about that. All other model design is consistent with the original.
After a few of my own designs for interlocking trays using magnets, I came across Popsicle_peon's design and liked it. After a few weeks of use however I found the fit to be a little tight. I also figured that others would want to use sleeved cards for this and other games and so I set about building the customizer you see here for Popsicle's design.
The customizer includes much to play with in the UI, and the code gives you full flexibility. I've tried to comment it to aid those learning to code and also to give me a few pointers should I need to return to it.
The primary unchangeable features in the UI are that the base and walls are 2mm thick and the gap on each side is 28mm to allow most thumbs to get in there. This leads to a minimum sensible card width or around 35mm, which I think should cater to almost all cards out there. Otherwise you're free to twiddle with card width, height and stack size. In addition, you can tweak the "breathing space" around the cards if you want more or less space. You can also adjust that in the stack size (or Z dimension). I'm sure you'll figure the rest out by fiddling.
If you do customize this, please share your customized result and give it a name that shows which card game (or sleeve size) you've dimensioned it for. I hope to see some of your makes and your table layouts using the system.

description.text: This is an add-on for Hogsqueal's awesome hanger setup. I ran into an issue that when the filament runs low, the spool tilts up and mostly off of the hanger. If you slip this thing over the part where the spool rests, you can effectively get a full flange on the end of the peg, keeping the spool in place through its lifetime. I actually ended up preferring this "band-aid" fix to a redesign of the hanger because it doesn't make it any harder to get the spools on or off, but solves the problem I was having.

title: Storage for Assault on Doomrock: Doompocalypse!

description.text:
This is a four-piece storage solution meant for Assault on Doomrock 2nd Edition and its expansion, Doompocalypse! These are designed to fit inside the Doompocalypse box. The four pieces are:
  • A "setup" tray, which is only used during game setup, containing the map cards, the setting deck, and the hero markers, cards, trait cards, and starting ability cards.
  • A token tray, which holds HP, shields/heroism, secret/time, silver/gold, and expose markers. This should stay accessible to players throughout adventuring.
  • A card tray, which holds the common and epic item decks, the ability cards (level ups), and the wilderness and mountain event cards. This should stay accessible to players throughout adventuring. (note: I would like to make this a bit taller so that the stacked dice don't poke up above the tray lip)
  • A "battle" tray, which contains the battle AI cards, the enemy boss and minion markers, the terrain cards, and all the terrain markers (large, small, and border). These components are only used during the battle phases, and thus this tray can be kept to the side until needed. (note: I had some serious layer adhesion issues and only had an entire functional print after five attempts, so I may need to redesign this one for a quicker print and more sturdy walls.)

I purchased a large 15x15" piece of 1/4" (6 mm) tempered glass to use a print bed and needed a way to safely support and secure the bed on a moving gantry. The system also allows for 3 point leveling. This system includes a glass clip and a mounting base. The base is fixed in positon while the glass can be removed from the base without removing the clips. This allows for easy cleaning and parts removal without affecting the bed leveling. This setup uses M5 hardware:
3- M5x8 Cap Screw
3 - M5 tee nuts
3 - M5x35 hex bolts
3 - M5 nuts - the narrow the better
3 - springs (1/2" x 7/8") in my case. The knob used was the M5 nut loose from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:641854 My printer has 20x20 OpenBuild V-slot rails for the gantry. The base is secured to the rails using a M5x8 cap screw and tee nut. The hole diameter in the base and the loose fitting nut in the knob provide some degree of freedom for adjusting the bed. The degreee of freedom works well on a large bed like this, but probably not as well on smaller beds. I haven't tested this but Basic directions:
Print the parts
Mount the bases
Assemble and install the glass clips
Mount the glass The base locations will need to be adjusted based on gantry layout, glass size, etc. I recommend keeping the bases a bit loose in the rail until you set the glass and then lock them down. Keep the bases near the edge of the glass so you can get a allen wrench under the glass to tighten them down. Note: The base shown above was an earlier version and not the final version. The hole is big enough for the M5 hex bolt but doesn't provide for bed angle adjustment.

Cobblebot Basic

Notes: I used white PLA for my prints. I used white because I could mark the adjustment directions right on the pieces. Really helps when bed leveling.

I designed this acoustic guitar mute to go over the hole of an acoustic nylon string guitar and really does impact the amount of sound coming out of the instrument. Ideal if you want to tear up your acoustic axe whilst NOT driving your housemates / neighbors crazy. The F holes are modeled after real ones from a violin and will definitely make you look a sophisticated and well cultured musician  :)

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

20%

Old beat-up violin finish with crackling effect Apart from the fake wood finish, I covered the back in 2mm black foam which helps better seal the hole, and eliminates the possibility of scratching the finish of your guitar. In order to keep things tightly in place, and help quickly place the device over the instrument's hole, I embedded a strong, thin neodymium magnet at the bottom of the outer rim of the mute; this, together with another larger neodymium magnet glued inside the guitar near the hole, makes it so you can just hold the mute close by the guitar hole and it will "jump" into place all by itself. Very handy if you are playing in the dark, yeah... 2mm black foam & flat round neodymium magnet.
This was entirely designed on Blender, except for the f holes, which were made on illustrator and exported later as svg...I know...whatever...it worked!

comments.text: Exporting an SVG file to Blender is exactly how I would have done it... Seems like an effective method to me. Although I wouldn't glue a magnet to the inside of my guitar.

title: Customizable - MatchStick Glider - Single print flying glider & bed leveling tool.

description.text: This glider is a great tool to check your bed-level! and in a single print you can have a fun toy to fly around the house, or the yard. Set the Size to set the length of the glider - wings, nose weight and tail are automatically scaled to flyable proportions. Set the flthick to the first Layer thickness you use on your printer- This will set the wing and tailfin thickness so only one layer is printed the Vertical stabilizer is on the bottom side. once printed, lay it on the edge of a table and give the elevators a crease upward. then pull the wing tips together to give the wings a slight upward dihedral angle. Give it a toss! Smaller versions (40-80mm fly OK indoors, you'll probably need to check that the wings and tail are straight after every throw, also toss it VERY softly for the little ones) Larger versions (120mm+ fly fairly well indoors or out - Full elevator deflection for loops!, and you can fling them as hard as you want!) Watch it printing! https://youtu.be/dEFvw7LRwAQ

Printer:

QUBD Two Up

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4mm or less.

Infill:

50% for proper flying weight.

Notes: Set flthick to match the First Layer thickness you normally print with. After Printing, pull the wingtips together for a little upward dihedral angle. flip the glider top down on a table and use the edge to crease the elevators upwards

title: Sony Action Cam Holder for Gopro Mount

description.text: This is a holder for the Sony Action Cam. I'm using it for an AS200 with lens protector. I wanted a quick way to put a camera in and out of the car without screwing and unscrewing, or even easier than clipping. It works together with the item below and a Gopro bike mount adapter. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1035054 I find that the camera sits in the box just fine. If you're concerned about it coming out then you can just put a rubber band around it or velcro. It has a slot cut out in it so a charging cable can be attached to the camera. The top and bottom are glued together. I used Acetone/ABS slurry for my glue so that the ABS would be bonded together. I'm sure any other glue would work just fine. **The STL isn't oriented right for printing, but I'm sure you can rotate it and figure it out.

author: Area51

description.text:
Suggested use:
  • Print the STL file with no raft, no support.
  • Pause the printer when the print is 75% complete, remove the heart box top and bottom pieces only. Paint the heart box red or decorate with colored markers as desired.
  • Insert a handwritten message and/or small jewelry item into the heart box, then drop the assembled heart box into the outer box and unpause the print, to "capture the heart."
  • When printing is complete, tie a a loop of red ribbon through the small holes in the corner of the outer box for decorative effect.
    • Notes:
    a. If you have a printer with dual extruders, print the heart box in red.
    b. If you are planning to insert a ring into the heart box, be sure to resize the print so that the ring will fit through the holes in the outer box. :-)
    c. The outer box also makes a good coin trap.
    d. The sample messages shown in the PNG files were generated with http://cooltext.com/ Jan. 30, 2017 Update: heart_box_v2 prints amazingly fast, with much better quality. I've removed the v1 files.

comments.author: ipblythe

comments.text:
:)
WRL isn't some closed source format. It's from VRML which is a markup language like that HTML thing.
It's used to define Virtual Reality Worlds and models and can be read by a number of open source programs such as Blender and Meshlab.

Wall thickness is 1.5mm, base is 1mm thick, lid is 1.5mm thick.
Lid isn't super snug, there is a ~1.5mm tolerance between the rim of the lid and the pot, this is just to make it easier to remove. Lid diameter is 1mm more than that of the pot to make it easier to remove. 
Designed with Google Sketchup, Design files included.
Update: I have added another lid with a deeper insert.. As the other one I had blew off in the wind.

This is my nose. I have no problem with you having my nose. Feel free to cast anything you'd like. I myself chose to cast a few bars of soap. Nothing smells better and cleans more fiercely than my nose.

How did I make my nose into a bar of soap? I used a Sense Scanner to scan my face then cropped all the unnecessary stuff (the rest of my face). From there, in Rhino, I used the mesh command Boolean Difference to cut out the scanned shape of my nose into a mesh block. I 3d printed that form. The soap is a simple melt and pour. The scent is cucumber melon.

description.text: This is a combination of the Mobius Strap and the Uke Leash. Both are strap solutions that don't require modifications to the ukulele. The Mobius Strap wouldn't work for me, as it requires a ukulele with a waist. The Flea doesn't have a waist. The Uke Leash was fairly complex. It is also narrow and made of nylon webbing. I wanted something softer (I went with cotton, as hemp was a bit pricey), and something wider. The cotton webbing cost $1.60 for about 2yds and that is more material than I needed. I customized the 2 triglides I listed as remix sources. Overall, I'm very pleased with the results. To really finish off the leash nicely, I need to figure out how to cleanly shore up the cut ends of the cotton webbing.

author: kevinrivero

title: Knobs for the Proxxon Micro Compound Table KT 70

description.text: The Proxxon table is a great, very precise tool, but the knobs/handles are too small for my taste, and I prefer some more chunky knobs that fit fingers, and would even allow for single-finger turning.

• Slice it in your favorite slicer (I used Netfabb and a 0.2mm layer height)
  • Print (I used my Ultimaker, and the fast 0.2mm #4 profile in the 4.8 release)
  • clean out the stringing (still working on optimizing the temperature and profile). Don't clean out too much of the strings on the inside, they add good friction when you push it onto the Proxxon wheels.
  • Drill a hole for the set screw (I did not include a hole for it in the model, since I don't know what screws you have lying around. Drill very slowly.
  • Push it onto the wheels, tighten the set screw. Done.

comments.text: Be careful with that KT70.

title: Logitech C270 Web Cam Gantry Mount for RigidBot

description.text:
I wanted a Gantry mounted camera on my Rigidbot that was fixed at the hot end at all times, and wouldn't require any extra hardware to install... This is it. 
This is designed for a Logitech C270 web-cam, though other Logitech cameras might fit. 
The camera is mounted such that it clears the bed and any printed objects that might be on it. I set it as far back as possible for the widest view, while still keeping the camera inside the frame of the RigidBot. It inserts snugly into beam on the side of the gantry and it's angled such that the camera lens will point to the exact center of the bed when the bed is centered. It hangs below the hot end so that you have an excellent view of it at all times. the only real "blind spot is if the hot end is tucked all the way toward the X motor, but correcting this blind spot while still keeping the camera in-bounds of the frame would have meant larger blind spots elsewhere.

Installing the Camera The camera must be removed from it's original mount. There are two rubber plugs on either end of the hinge that need to be removed (I used an xacto knife), then there is a small philips screw in one side, remove the screw then push out the plastic hinge pin. to free the camera. The hinge pin and screw will need to be reused to install the camera on the mount, There is enough room to insert the hinge pin from the inside edge. There are anti-rotation flats inside the mount so if insertion is difficult make sure the pin is aligned properly. Once through you can snug up the philips screw on the outside edge to keep the pin from backing out. This should be snug enough that the camera will hold it's position without sagging. Once the camera is installed on the mount it can be inserted into the gantry beam. Again this should be snug to keep it moving around, but you may need to use a razor to shave down any edges that might have spurs or ooze that might be keeping it from inserting all the way.

comments.text: One suggestion as a possible update.  You have the anti-rotation flats as the top and bottom surfaces of the mounting pin holes.  Seems like those flats could go vertically in the holes (so they would be left and right 'walls' instead of top and bottom 'floors') and that would decrease the amount of bridging necessary in the print.

A simple wooden padlock that is "psychologically locked". The usual methods people use to open this will actually STOP them from opening it. :-)
Most people will try to grab the front and back and try to counter-twist. This lock is only 1" x .75" x 1.25" (closed) I recommend sanding the wood BEFORE cutting. this keeps all the wood the same thickness and the scorching makes it look more rustic. :-) Last, itty-bitty note: I messed up when assembling the lock in the picture. The 'Perm' panels are upside-down. :-/

Special Instructions Wipe all edges, please, as I'm sure you know. :-) Due to my inability to accurately describe the assembly process with words, I have included a picture with the instructions that should help an awful lot. It's really not that hard as long as you pay attention to alignment. To open: twist BOTH 'Perm' panels until they stop. The Shackle should now slide free.
To lock: seat the shackle, and return 'Perm's to lock position

title: Ethernet Cable Runners
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Ethernet Cable Runners provide a simple solution to keep your Ethernet cables neat, under control and easy to access, insert and remove. The range accommodates from 2 to 16 cables. Each slot only ever accepts up to 2 cables. This ensures you can easily access and remove inner cables...the maximum that can be outside it is one. There are also three types. The standard type is for use unsecured along the floor or across a desk. The other two types have two types to secure the Ethernet Cable Runners with a cable / zip tie. Type "T" has the slot aligned inline with the cables direction. Type "T90" has the slot rotated 90 degrees from the cable direction. The slot is suitable for use with medium size cable ties. This allow bunches on cables to be run along under shelves / racking. Refer to the images for more information. I have also provided a screw mounting version of the range at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1471789. This should make it easier for people to find the type best suited to the need. They are all small blocks that print quickly so are an easy and cost effective solution to an everyday issue in offices and at home. Print lots and a range so you've always got the right one to fulfil your need at the time.... Tidy up your cables today! And, if the cables you're using vary from common size Ethernet cables, just uniformly scale them to suit. Please refer to the images and print instructions for further information. Note: If you like these check out the rest of my practical and fun designs. Other useful designs related to Cable Management are at the links below... Cable Coiler - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764247
Cable Corners - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1182945
Cable Manager - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1107638
Ethernet Port Protector Plug - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:685956

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

No

Standard / 0.20mm

3 Shells / 50% infill / PLA recommended

Notes: To make sure these work well print them strong by using 3 shells and 50% infill. They work great in PLA. They should also print well in ABS. If you find the cables you're using vary from common size Ethernet cables, just uniformly scale them to suit.
Just remove the Raft and push in your cables.... Tell us more...

comments.text: I'm assuming you still haven't resolved this... I can only base my comments on how the MakerBot app works and in that case you don't see the .stl file when printing via the app. you just connect the app / phone to the printer then (within the app) navigate to the design you want to print... tap on the image of the design and the app does the rest. It will download the file and send it to print. You do not download the .stl as a separate part of the process. With the MakerBot app it really is that simple... with a computer you download the .stl then import it into the application. The mobile app is much leaner... so simpler but it doesn't allow you to change print settings which can be critical to the strength of the print.

author: Sagolla

description.text:
I built this as a filament guide for my printer, i have my drybox on top of the enclosure and run my filament in the back wall, so i needed a nice 180* turnaround for the material, its intended to be mounted on 1/8" flatbar (i am using aluminum 3/4" x 1/8") with a single m3 (or similar) machine screw and nut, the bearing used is a standard skateboard bearing 8mm inside 22mm outside and 7mm wide. And i intend to glue the "cap" piece in place after inserting the bearing and roller piece, it will likely all need some post work (sanding) as i intended the piece on the outer of the bearing to be press fit.
I tried to design it to be printed easily without supports.
the first version was a little tight turn, and the filament would fall off, so i designed a couple more models, larger as well, same bearing, i did print and currently use "v2" but it does require more material, so i designed but untested v3.
Edit again: I've been using v2 a couple months since i designed it, works well.

description.text:
Snowflake Tree Ornament for your Xmass tree and/or gifts.
Source is Rhino 3D format (version 3.0). Initially I haven't printed this out due to storm tossing the boat around that night. But hearing that we're likely to have a supply of PLA soon in the US I felt inspired.

Ideally to be printed in PLA so it's transparent but are waiting for Makerbot Industries to have it in stock in the USA. I made my first successful 5cm print into a Xmass Pendant.
and a smaller (dainty) 4cm for my girlfriend. I imagine the source file could be converted and lasercut in acrylic as well. I've exported to STEP (.stp) if someone wants to play around with the source some since that seems to be a more universal format than Rhino3d.

description.text: I created an image of a large shark jumping out of the ocean trying to catch a runaway fish. The fish is rather small and barley is out of reach. This was printing into an acrylic tile with a CNC laser.

I used Adobe Illustrator to crate my image and then saved it to my computer. After changing various preferences (raster speed %100, raster power %50, vector speed %12, vector power %100, vector frequency 5000hz) and setup tecniques (autofocus on) it was time to print. I sent the image to the CNC laser machine and put a large piece of blue acrylic in the machine. After about five minutes cutting the laser printed my exact image on the acrylic.

There are lots of coin traps on Thingiverse, but I haven't seen any designs that embed one trap inside another. Here's how to do it (assuming your 3D printer is capable of pausing a print in progress, which not all of them are):
  • Begin the print (I used no raft, no support, although you can add one or both if you must).
  • When the smaller coin trap is about two-thirds printed, pause the printer and drop a coin into the center. A Canadian or American 10-cent piece fits very nicely. Be sure that the coin does not protrude above the printed area.
  • Continue the print. When the smaller coin trap is completed (with the coin trapped inside), pause the printer again. Remove the smaller coin trap from the print bed and drop it into the larger coin trap, again ensuring that the smaller (inner) object does not protrude higher than the side walls of the larger (outer) object.
  • Unpause the print one last time.
    • Notes
    a) Try rotating the completed object on a flat surface. On my test print, the inner (spheroid) object always aligns itself with the outer (cubic) object, which looks pretty cool.
    b) These objects were made with Meshmixer 3.0.

I purchased a precision screw driver from Princess Auto. I'm happy with the screw driver, but the plastic insert that holds all of the bits wasn't any good. The plastic was too flimsy, so when you tried to press the bit into its slot it collapsed so that it wouldn't fit. It was quite difficult to get them back in after removing them. As you can see in the pictures the plastic cracked in a few places.
So, I designed this to replace it and it's working great. Hopefully there is someone else who has one, or has a use for this.

description.text:
This customizable mouthstick will work with capacitive tablets such as the iPad and Android devices if printed with conductive PLA and a conductive sponge is inserted in the tip. I am still working on tweaking the open scad files, but it prints okay.
This is a mouth stick designed as assistive technology for a person with no use of their hands, and is used to type on keyboards, flip pages in books, and to dial phones. When printed with a conductive plastic it will work with capacitance touch screens such as the iPad, iPhone, and Android tablets. The one I printed is made with Protopasta. There is a conductive foam tip installed in the end to made it more responsive. I used a small piece cut from a fresh, unused ScotchBrite sponge, but any conductive sponge will do. Once the mouth stick is printed, it can be custom sized and bends made by heating it up with a heat gun.
For more information on assistive technology, visit http://www.rehabengineer.com, or our agency at http://rehab.alabama.gov/ .

title: Window-Holder // Scheibenhalter CTC Dual / Flashforge Creator / MakerBot Replicator 1

description.text:
ENGLISH --- DEUTSCH WEITER UNTEN
Window-holder for the CTC Dual 3D printer (should fit at identical FlashForge Creator and MakerBot Replicator 1, too). This is a remix of the window-holder from xxricsxx. In my version, all windows are simply hooked, this is quite adequate in my eyes. If you like it a little more stable, also prints the lower parts, in which the windows are then supported. What is needed in addition to the printed parts is Plexiglas in the following dimensions:
2 pieces: 250 x 250 x 5 mm
1 piece: 410 x 250 x 5 mm
At the front window, the two upper corners have to be cut, as otherwise the screws of the housing in the path. I have simply cut off a triangle with an edge length of 4 cm at 45 °, which then fits perfectly! The (upper) parts have holes for M3 screws. This work I have saved me, as I have just connected both with Revell model glue (Revell Contacta). Holds perfectly! DEUTSCH
Scheibenhalterung für den CTC Dual 3D-Drucker (sollte beim baugleichen Flashforge Creator und Makerbot Replicator 1 ebenso passen). Es handelt sich hierbei um einen Remix des Scheibenhalters von xxricsxx. In meiner Version sind alle Scheiben einfach eingehängt, was in meinen Augen völlig ausreichend ist. Wer es etwas stabiler mag, der druckt auch die unteren Teile, in denen die Scheiben dann abgestützt werden. Benötigt werden außer den Druckteilen nur Plexiglas-Scheiben in den folgenden Abmessungen: 2 Stück: 250 x 250 x 5 mm
1 Stück: 410 x 250 x 5 mm Bei der Frontscheibe müssen die beiden oberen Ecken abgesägt werden, da sonst die Schrauben des Gehäuses im Weg sind. Ich habe hier im 45°-Winkel einfach ein Dreieck mit der Kantenlänge 4 cm abgesägt, das passt dann ideal! Die (oberen) Teile haben Löcher für M3-Schrauben. Diese Arbeit habe ich mir gespart, indem ich einfach beides mit Revell-Modellbaukleber verbunden habe (Revell Contacta). Hält einwandfrei! Aktuelles zu meinen 3D-Druck-Projekten und Verbesserungen für den CTC immer auf meinem Blog www.modellpilotenblog.de

CTC Dual

description.text:
This is a Cookie Cat cookie cutter inspired by dougwinning99's well-done design. I was originally going to simply print his, but the prints didn't come out so well for me (model had overlapping errors, thin walls made it pretty fragile, eyes weren't well supported, etc).
I completely remodeled the design from scratch, fixing all of the mesh errors in the original model. It is also considerably thicker, and the eyes are better supported, making it very sturdy. The cutting part of the piece also comes to a peak now, making it a little bit easier to use, and allowing the piece to be thicker without affecting the shape of the cookies too much.
EDIT: added small hole to eyes to make cleaning easier.
I have included the OBJ file in case anyone wants to easily adjust the proportions (e.g. make the eyes bigger, change the supports, etc.)

A working surfboard (wake-surf board, in this case) fin.  Fitted with mounting tabs for RONIX surfboard.

Early version of this fin broke off due to high side loads.  I recommending printing at 100% infill.  I also increased the base thickness so that side loads are transferred to the main body of the fin, rather than being all absorbed by the tabs.  
Time to print at 100% infill (on Makerbot 2): 6 hours

I had a design I made etched out onto a piece of acrylic using a CNC laser. The design I made was a man jumping from one building to another and titled parkour.

• I first opened Adobe Illustrator
  • Created the design I had choosen
  • Clicked print, then setup, then preferences
  • I made the speed of the raster cut 100%
  • I made the power of the raster cut 50%
  • I made the speed of the vector cut 12%
  • I made the power of the vector cut 100%
  • I made the frequency of the vector cut 5000 hertz
  • I checkec the combined box for vector and raster
  • I checked the auto-focus box
  • I then printed the design to the CNC laser
  • I placed in my blue piece of acrylic and had the machine print my piece
  • Once it was finished I took out my piece and took pictures
  • I lastly uploaded it to Thingiverse

This thing provides the ability to generate connector caps for male pins, such as the GPIO connector on a Raspberry pi, uln2003 stepper motor driver boards and probably others. You can use this link to configure customised variants: http://openjscad.org/#http://www.geminidev.be/3d/gpio2.jscad Note that the generated STL will need to be repaired using netfabb or similar for some slicers to handle.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Notes: Print as oriented - rotating it such that the pins run from top to bottom results in a poor print. All default variables are multiples of 0.25mm, hence slicing it at 0.25 provides the best results. Your own customisations may change this if you want. I would suggest printing slow and trying to remove any oozed filament before the print starts as everything is quite delicate and erroneously extruded filament could block the hole or misshape the print.

description.text: Recently Gene Editing has been in the news. With the development of this technology, it is now possible to edit the DNA of humans and other organisms. Lesson Plans and lab work is now available on my teacher pay teacher site, https://www.teacherspayteachers.com/Product/3D-Printable-DNA-RNA-Manipulative-Lab-1-3452084 Gene editing is also known as genetic modification, gene splicing, genome editing, or gene therapy. All of them use restriction enzymes / nucleases "Molecular scissors" to cut and splice different genes into the host DNA. In looking online, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome_editing, there are thousand of different nucleases that work in different way to edit DNA. To model nucleases, I designed this expansion set for my DNA / RNA manipulative set. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259352 Using these DNA blocks, you can easily move and manipulate your choice of nucleates. In the file I include 1 bp and 6 bp block so you can explore the most common restriction enzymes. I did simplify this by removing the phosphate group (P) block from this. I did this in order to save space on your students desktop.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3 mm

Infill:

5-10%

Notes: Print in clear or a color not used with the rest of the DNA set. I included the 3 prime and 5 prime tag files so you can mark which end your DNA is spliced. Put a piece of clear packing tape over the blank space, use a dry erase marker to write the name of your restriction enzyme.

Expansion Set This is an expansion set built from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259352 Print up the DNA set first, the use the base pairs (A,T,C,G) inside the slots of the D pieces. This was designed in TinkerCAD.

PROJECT: Gene Editing These pieces are to expand upon students knowledge of DNA and gene editing. Students can use these to produce their own restriction enzymes / nucleases. They can further uses these to demonstrate their knowledge of gene editing, and model the restriction enzymes used in gene editing. Objectives Students will demonstrate and describe gene editing.
Students will model the different types of restriction enzymes.
Students will explore the ethics and implications of gene editing.
Students will explore how to cure genetic disease with gene editing. Genetic students
Genetic students should demonstrate the different types of mutations used in gene editing.
Genetic students should demonstrate the different restriction enzymes used.
Genetic students should demonstrate how to select the restriction enzymes to use for any procedure. Audiences This is intended for AP Biology, College biology, genetics students. It can also be used by genetic researchers, gene councilors, or medical professionals. Preparation Students should already know about DNA, RNA, and restriction enzymes.
Students should already know that gene editing is a new process to modify DNA.
Students should know the parts of the model set, and how to manipulate them into DNA code.
Students should know the different types of mutations. Teachers should 3D print at least 2 (6D) blocks per team. Teachers should prepare reading or videos that show how restriction enzymes work. Steps a. Model how a restriction enzyme works and how it cuts DNA along specific sequences.
b. Model how these restriction enzymes can insert, delete, or otherwise mutate DNA.
c. Model how gene editing would happen for a specific disease.
d. Model how to edit a gene for a specific sequence, showing how the DNA is altered from original to new DNA.
e. Explore the legal and ethical ramifications for gene editing.
f. Have students engage in presidential style debate for the pros / cons of gene editing.
g. Have the student prepare a report to go before a congressional hearing or medical panel. consider have students present before medical professionals.
h. Have students present the process to others or underclassmen. Results When finished, students should demonstrate the following.
a. The process of gene editing.
b. The use of restriction enzymes.
c. The process of mutating DNA to fit our intent.
d. Understand the legal and ethical ramifications for gene editing

title: Double j-head / E3D mount (for Orca or whatever..)

description.text:
Update 2016-06-26
Beware this is work in progress. I just found out this version will not fit into Orca v4x. I will rework a 90 degree version that will. This is a mount, to attach 2 J-heads or E3D hotends to a printer.
It is derived from a regular J-head mount (as in Rostocks or Delta's). In my situation it is for mounting on my Orca v4x Be aware: This is the clamp for the J-head. You need to adjust your x-place accordingly. There are 2 versions, a long one (derived from Delta plates and a short one that will fit between the x-rods of an Orca v3/v4
09-02-2016 Slide plate for the short version published. i will publish a revised Orca X-plate in near future. Please LIKE before collecting Thomas
